narration.#text: Hello and welcome to the eScore Reference Manual lesson. Navigating through this course is easy, just use the arrows at bottom-right side of the screen to go forward and back. Enjoy your eScore training.

pText.#text:
Empowered with access to:

  • Rebate schedule
  • TVA Installation Standards
  • Health and safety requirements
  • Terms and definitions, and
  • So much more

narration.#text:
The purpose of this course is to empower you with the tools you need to participate in the eScore™ program.

With the electronic version of the eScore™ Reference Manual, or eRM, you will be able to quickly access the rebate schedule, TVA Installation Standards, Health and Safety requirements, terms and definitions, and so much more.

Click next to begin.

We’ve made the eRM easy for you to access wherever you’re at:


  • View it now from your lesson
  • Login to the portal and download it from the training reference panel, or
  • Open it on your eScore™ phone or tablet

In addition, you’ll receive a printed copy and other great resources at your scheduled classroom training.

Click next.

pText.#text:
Download Instructions

1. Go to your eScore™ portal

2. Right-click eScore Reference Manual

link and select:

  • "Save Link As...", or
  • "Save target as..."

3. Open the eRM from your computer

HELP LINKS

  • Need help finding the eRM on your computer?
  • Need Acrobat Reader?
  • Need help opening the eRM with Acrobat Reader?

narration.#text:
As part of this lesson, you will need to download a copy of the eRM to your computer so you can perform the lesson exercises. To do this,

1.First, go to your eScore portal

2.Second, right-click the eScore Reference Manual, select “Save Link As…” or “Save target as…”, and save it to your desktop, and

3.Third, open the eRM from your computer

It’s best to open the eRM using Acrobat Reader. Use the Help links to download Acrobat Reader or for more for instructions on how to open the eRM.

There are lots of ways to find what you need in the eRM PDF. The easiest way is to use the bookmarks. Here you can jump to the table of contents or any of the main pages.

From the table of contents you can link to each section… and page.

There are even hyperlinks within each page that will take you to some great resources like the Energy Star home page.

If you’re searching for specific words or standards, use the search function in Edit… then Find.

As you could probably tell, the eRM is made up of a combination of several printed documents with their own printed page numbers. To make it easier navigate, this lesson will use the PDF page numbers instead of the printed page numbers.

For example, a quiz question might reference the Climate Zones on eRM page 71. If you type 71 and press Enter, you can see a copy of the Climate Zones on eRM page 71.

Click next to see if you can navigate the eRM.

initPrompt.#text: Locate the Energy Upgrade Sheets link in the table of contents (eRM pages 2-3).

mobileInitPrompt.#text: Locate the Energy Upgrade Sheets link in the table of contents (eRM pages 2-3).

triesFeedback.#text: Incorrect, try again. You can find the Upgrade Sheets in the Collateral section of the eRM.

incorrectFeedback.#text: Incorrect. The correct path is Bookmark > Collateral > Energy Upgrade Sheets > Air Sealing (eRM page 251)

questionText.#text: Now it’s your turn to start using the eRM. (1) Open the eScore™ Reference Manual.pdf on your computer. (2) Use the bookmarks or table of contents to find which page the Air Sealing Energy Upgrade Sheet is on.

narration.#text:
There are 4 main sections to the eRM:

  • Tab 1: Program Description
  • Tab 2: Quality Contractor Network Materials
  • Tab 3: TVA Standards, and
  • Fourth section is Collateral

Though we’ll not cover these sections in detail in this lesson, it’s your responsibility to become familiar with the workings of the eScore™ program and the TVA standards.

pText.#text:
How the eScore™ program works:

  • Homeowner evaluation options
  • How participants qualify and initiate the evaluation or inspection
  • Rebate Schedule
  • Sample score card

narration.#text:
You will use the Program Description section of the eRM to quickly access how the eScore™ program works including:

  • The Homeowner evaluation options
  • How participants qualify and initiate the evaluation or inspection
  • The Rebate Schedule, and
  • Sample score card

pText.#text:
Quality Contractor Network Materials:

  • Requirements for joining the QCN
  • Privileges of membership, including use of TVA logos and eScore Rewards
  • Requirements to stay a member, and
  • The Removal process for not meeting the requirements

narration.#text:
The Quality Contractor Network Materials section will give you specifics on:

  • Requirements for joining the QCN
  • Privileges of membership, including use of TVA logos and eScore Rewards
  • Requirements to stay a member, and
  • The Removal process for not meeting the requirements

pText.#text:
TVA Standards section:

  • Inspection and scoring process
  • Qualified materials and products
  • Health and safety
  • Five primary areas of inspection

narration.#text:
The TVA Standards section is the largest part of the eRM and will provide you with detailed information on:

  • The inspection and scoring process
  • Qualified materials and products
  • Health and safety, and the
  • Five primary areas of inspection
The last section is Collateral. This is where you’ll find the requirements for using the TVA and eScore™ logos and see all 10 of the Energy Upgrade sheets for each point of inspection.

instructionText.#text:
For your convenience we will provide you with a few different formats of the TVA Standards.

Click each image to learn more about the four different formats of standards. When you have viewed all four, click next to move on.

mobileInstructionText.#text:
For your convenience we will provide you with a few different formats of the TVA Standards.

Tap each image to learn more about the four different formats of standards. When you have viewed all four, click next to move on.

image1text.#text: In addition to the eRM, you will receive a printed binder that will include ALL the installation requirements and the alpha-numeric upgrade codes e.g. ASL-09, ASL-22, etc. (PDF)

image2text.#text: This conveniently sized printed book is a little more portable (8.5” x 5.5”). In it you’ll have a summary of the TVA Standards, matching Upgrade Codes, and helpful formulas, procedures and photos. (PDF)

image3text.#text: These are single-page printed brochures that summarize each of the 10 energy upgrades. The front-side answers the question, “Why should I upgrade?”. The backside answers the question, “How should it be done?” i.e. what are the requirements for installing the energy upgrades. (PDF)

image4text.#text: Here is a handy pocket-sized checklist for each upgrade. The front-side shows a high-level list of requirements and the backside gives you the required data points that need to be met before submitting an application. (PDF)

narration.#text:
The TVA Standards section of the eRM defines the standards and best practices that support the safe and effective installation of energy upgrades in existing homes.

While it is not a requirement for you to memorize the standards document, it is essential that you become familiar with it so that you can use it and reference it efficiently. Here are some of the key points to help you –

Know that in the document, requirements using the word “shall”, mean that the action specified is mandatory and must be done by the QCN member.

When “should” or “recommend” are used, know that QCN members are encouraged, but not required, to follow the best practices for installing the applicable energy upgrades. The best practices text will also be italicized.

Important terms are underlined throughout the document and are explained in greater detail on the Definitions pages.

Click next to learn about the new scoring system for the inspection process.

instructionText.#text:
This activity will help you become familiar with the inspection process scoring system. Place you cursor over each score to see its definition.

When you have the scoring definitions memorized, click Practice to test yourself by dragging-and-dropping the inspection score onto the matching definition.

instructionTextDD.#text: Let's see how well you know the inspection scores. Drag the score to the correct definition.

reviewMobileInst.#text: This activity will help you become familiar with the inspection process scoring system. Tap the inspection scores to see their definitions. When you have them memorized, tap the Practice button to test yourself.

practiceMobileInst.#text: Let's see how well you know the inspection scores. Tap a inspection score and then tap the matching definition below.

defText.#text: The installation passes the TVA standards and the installation was completed according the rebate request.
The installation passes TVA Standards but the inspector had to provide technical assistance to the QCN member to correct deficiencies.
The installation failed. The inspector identified minor problems that have only minor impacts on the savings or overall quality of the installation.

The installation failed and there is an urgent response needed. Items in this area include major problems with the quality of the job, dangerous conditions, or inaccurate and misleading rebate documentation.

narration.#text: Next in the TVA Standards section is the list of specific products that may be used in the program. Note that this list is not exclusive and, with TVA approval, QCN members may use other products such as different types of sealants, insulation materials, attic hatch covers, duct mastic, and many others.

The Health and Safety section begins with the health and safety requirements regarding combustion appliances, lead, etc., and then includes best practices when dealing with hazardous situations and materials.

These TVA Standards are based on an extensive list of nationally recognized standards and best practices.

Click Next to preview the 5 primary sections of the TVA Standards.

The 5 primary sections of the TVA Standards are:

  • Air Sealing
  • Insulation
  • Windows and Doors
  • Water Heater, and
  • Heating and Cooling

As you can see, each section begins with the upgrade requirements that summarize the entire section. Typically this may be all that you need for most jobs.

Another helpful hint is, when you view the TVA Standards table of contents, all the rebate upgrades are bolded like this. Simply click an upgrade requirement from the table of contents and you’ll be linked to the standard specifications that you need.

That’s how get around the eRM and the TVA Standards. Click next when you’re ready to test you what you’ve learned.

correctFeedback.#text: Good. Click next to test your ability to reference the eRM quickly.

introText.#text:
The purpose of this challenge is to help you determine if you have mastered the objectives in the eScore™ Reference Manual lesson:

  • Download and view the eRM
  • Locate and identify specific upgrades on the eScore™ Participant Rebate Schedule
  • Use the eRM to list the new inspection scoring criteria
  • Search the eRM to locate the Minimum Efficiency Requirements for Heating and Cooling

    • Note: You CAN use the eRM during the challenge and you can retake the challenge after you review your results.
introText.heading: eRM Summary Challenge

distractor.iFeedback: Good. Click next to test your ability to reference the eRM quickly.
Repeat the Download the eRM page or contact CSG for assistance before moving on: 1-855-237-2673 | escore@csgrp.com

questionText.#text: Were you able to download the eScore Reference Manual.pdf?

popup_instruction.#text:
In this challenge, first locate the eScore™ Participant Rebate Schedule in the eRM.

Next, drag the upgrade on the left to the rebate on the right. If the match is correct, a green line will appear. If the answer is wrong, a red line will appear and you can try again with a different upgrade. Hurry up, before the timer runs out!

instruction_page1.#text: Drag the upgrade on the left to the rebate on the right. Hurry up, before the timer runs out!

instruction_page2.#text: Click on the “Correct Responses” icon to view the correct answers.  Click on the “My Responses” icon to view your responses.

narration.#text:
In this challenge, first locate the eScore™ Participant Rebate Schedule in the eRM.

Next, drag the upgrade on the left to the rebate on the right. If the match is correct, a green line will appear. If the answer is wrong, a red line will appear and you can try again with a different upgrade. Hurry up, before the timer runs out!

distractor.#text: P1 means, it passes the TVA standards and the installation was completed according the rebate request.
P2 means it passes TVA Standards but the inspector had to provide technical assistance to the QCN member to correct deficiencies.
F3 means the installation failed. The inspector identified minor problems that have only minor impacts on the savings or overall quality of the installation.

F4 means the installation failed and there is an urgent response needed. Items in this area include major problems with the quality of the job, dangerous conditions, or inaccurate and misleading rebate documentation.

F3 means the installation failed and there is an urgent response needed. Items in this area include major problems with the quality of the job, dangerous conditions or inaccurate and misleading rebate documentation.
F4 means the installation failed. The inspector identified minor problems that have only minor impacts on the savings or overall quality of the installation.
P2 means, it passes the TVA standards and the installation was completed according the rebate request.
P1 means it passes TVA Standards but the inspector had to provide technical assistance to the QCN member to correct deficiencies.

correctFeedback.#text: Correct: That’s right! You are ready for eScore™.

triesFeedback.#text: Not there yet. Compare this list with eRM pages 52-53.

questionText.#text: Below are definitions from the new scoring system. Use the eRM to help you identify which 4 descriptions are correct.

correctFeedback.#text: That’s right! You are ready for eScore™.

incorrectFeedback.#text: Incorrect: Incorrect. The correct answers are SEER 14, HSPF 8, and EER 11. (See eRM page 242)

triesFeedback.#text: Give it one more try. Compare this list with eRM page 242.

questionText.#text: Using the Minimum Efficiency Requirements for Heating and Cooling in the eRM, identify which of the following is the correct efficiency requirement for Package Heat Pumps.

introText.#text:
The purpose of this practice quiz is to help you determine if you have gained a mastery of the TVA Standards and are ready for the eScore™ TVA Standards Certification Test.

Note: There are 10 questions, you must score 80% to pass, and you can retake the quiz after you have completed the quiz and reviewed your results.
introText.heading: TVA Standards Practice Quiz

distractor.#text: The word “shall” means that the action specified is mandatory and must be accomplished by the QCN member.
Best Practices are stated in the TVA Standards using the words “should” and “recommend” and appear in an italic font.
The word “should” means that the action specified is mandatory and must be accomplished by the QCN member.
Best Practices are stated in the TVA Standards using the words “shall” and “required” and appear in an italic font.

initPrompt.#text: Select all the answers that apply.

triesFeedback.#text: Incorrect, try again. (See the Overview of TVA Standards Documents in the eRM)

mobileInitPrompt.#text: Select all the answers that apply.

incorrectFeedback.#text: Incorrect. (See answers on pages 48 and 49 in the eRM)

questionText.#text: In the TVA Standards, what is the difference between the “shall” and “should” requirements? Select the best definition for each term.

correctFeedback.#text: Correct. No air sealing material shall be in contact with a heat-dissipating device unless it is fireproof.

incorrectFeedback.#text: Incorrect. No air sealing material shall be in contact with a heat-dissipating device unless it is fireproof. (See ASL-13, eRM page 77)

questionText.#text: True or False: All air sealing materials are rated for contact with the heat-dissipating devices.

correctFeedback.#text: Correct. The duct minimum insulation level is R-8. (See H&C-102, eRM page 201)

incorrectFeedback.#text: Incorrect. The duct minimum insulation level is R-8. (See H&C-102, eRM page 201)

questionText.#text: True or False: The minimum insulation level of all newly installed ductwork shall be R-6?

triesFeedback.#text: Not quite, try again. You can find help in the Air Sealing: General Standards for All Locations section of the eRM.

initPrompt.#text: Drag-and-drop the numbers onto the appropriate step.

mobileInitPrompt.#text: Tap a an air sealing requirement to put the steps in order.

questionText.#text: Put the air sealing requirements in order.

triesFeedback.#text: That’s not it, try again. (See the Attic Insulation: Kneewalls section of the eRM)

incorrectFeedback.#text: Incorrect. (See AIN-40, eRM page 126; H&C-03, eRM page 180)

questionText.#text: Fill in the blank: Kneewall insulation materials shall be installed to a minimum composite insulation value of ____ if existing, effective insulation level is less than R-11, or anytime kneewall insulation is added.

triesFeedback.#text: Not quite, try again. (See Attic Insulation Kneewalls in the eRM)

questionText.#text: What code suggests that unconditioned attic space cavities under kneewalls should be blocked and air sealed as a best practice?

correctFeedback.#text: Correct! Tubular skylights are not eligible for rebates.

incorrectFeedback.#text: Incorrect. Tubular skylights are not eligible for rebates. (See WND-30, eMR page 168)

questionText.#text: True or False: Tubular skylights are eligible for rebates if they are installed in qualifying homes to replace existing skylights that are damaged.

correctFeedback.#text: Correct! In two-story, or multi-level residences, there shall be a minimum of one return air grille on each level.

triesFeedback.#text: Not quite, try again. (See Heating and Cooling: Duct Design and Support in the eRM)

incorrectFeedback.#text: Incorrect. In two-story, or multi-level residences, there shall be a minimum of one return air grille on each level. (See H&C-85, eRM page 198)

questionText.#text: How many returns are required on a 2-story or multi-level residence?
Do prime windows need to have NFRC stickers on them?

distractor.#text: The perimeter of the pull down stair frame opening should be weather-stripped.
Cracks between wood trim and ceiling finish materials should be sealed around the perimeter of the opening with a compatible sealant.
Mechanical fasteners should be used where necessary to ensure tight closure.
Provide a continuous air barrier between conditioned and unconditioned spaces in the attic.
Use R-18 loose-fill insulation between attic ladder rungs.

triesFeedback.#text: Not quite. See the Attic Insulation section of the TVA Standards and try again.

questionText.#text: Look at the picture and identify all the standards that apply when applying for an Air Sealing rebate.
